comment._content: Great photo, excellent color and contrast. Cold as a plumbers....

comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Social Documentary Photography & events, and we'd love to have your photo added to the group.

comment.author: 10213344@N07
comment._content: Whimsical and shows that they sure didn't worry about people stealing their wares in this time and age. I love the colors in this photo and all the different shapes of plumbing supplies. Its like looking at a puzzle.  The more you look the more you see something new.

comment.author: 23032734@N06
comment._content:
Hey Fotos, if you read the Rights Info the photograph is Public Domain, it can be used by anyone.

I think this photograph shows how 'what goes around comes around'. Though mayhaps for different reasons. When this picture was taken money was tight so used was an option. Then the U.S. went through a period where new was the only way to go, only the 'disadvantaged' bought used. Used clothes, used materials, and so on. (Of course this does not include the antiques and collectibles).

About a decade ago the used market really took off and became mainstream. I seem to remember This Old House shopping in junkyards.

Round it goes ...

comment.author: 23073620@N00
comment._content: Is '1914' a tag that really makes sense for this photo? The only connection between the date and the photo is that the photographer happened to be born in 1914, which isn't really relevant to the photo or the subject. If I was searching for "1914" I would be looking for photos taken in 1914, or having some connection to things that happened in 1914. Popping up a bunch of results with the only connection being the birthdate of the author of the work would be annoying, to say the least.

comment.author: 43956296@N03
comment._content: very good idea to make '30-40 in color

comment.author: 53704511@N07
comment._content: I think this building still exists. It may be the old hardware store on Pleasant Street.

comment.author: 51966721@N03
comment._content: @Fallen4238... I grew up in Brockton, 1963 until around the late '80s.  This was the old junky hardware store on Pleasant St.  Don't know if it's still there but it was, and looked more or less like the photo, until at least the late '80s -- just had fewer fixtures strewn about the yard, and that cool paint color had warn off.  I remember it being more of a dirty warn gray color all over, like shown in upper story.

comment.author: 90576332@N07
comment._content: I believe this building was located on the corner of N. Montello Street and Porter Pass. If you zoom in on the front window you can see the reflection of a sign across the street that appears to be the Woodward's Auto Spring Company that was (and still is) in business in 1940. Also there is a title transfer record indicating that Peter Saba sold a lot at this same location to the Tilo Roofing company in 1946.

comment.author: 77975599@N03
comment._content: When this photo was taken, Saba and others like this still had a lot of inventory because we were coming out of the worse decade in history, the Depression.  During that period, nothing was thrown away or discarded, it was used and reused and many considered themselves lucky to get it reused for a third time.  WWII brought the final close to the Depression.  Those of us that are direct descendants of that time, still in old age, tend to save things.

comment.author: 44592226@N03
comment._content:
Does anyone have more infor or other pictures of this building.?  I just finished making an HO scale -1/87- model of it from my own plans. And would like the location of where it was. I checked both street informaton given but not there anymore.  
Any info of what the other side and back looked like? Was the whole building painted orange or just the front and sides?
And would you believe there is a model kit of this building for sale for about $150! 
Not very accurate, less trim and the windows are all wrong. 
Thanks for any info.
Bob D
rrdeffinger@msn.com

comment.author: 97031535@N06
comment._content: where can I buy framed copies of these pictures?  Love them!!

comment.author: 97166026@N08
comment._content: this was my Grandfathers second hand business,with his sons. Abdu Saba, Edward and Peter Lumpy Saba. My mother Helena Saba Stulpin said they had everything from old tubs to antiques. Abdu came over from the old country and was a business man in the hey day. they bought a house on Elliott St. this business was on No  Montello St.

comment.author: 63860770@N07
comment._content: lipolady, thanks for the additional information. We've had quite a few people who recognize the buildings or themselves in the FSA photos. We have a black and white version of this photo at www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/fsa/item/fsa2000024388/PP... and a close up photo of some of the items on the porch at www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/fsa/item/fsa2000024403/PP.... I would have never guessed the true color of the building from seeing just the black and white photos. twoconfusedpnl, if you go to the catalog record for this photo at hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/fsac.1a33851, you can download a high quality TIFF version that you can print yourself, or have printed. You can also purchase an unframed photograph through the Library's Duplication Services at www.loc.gov/duplicationservices/.
